Message.Title: Qualcomm not afraid of Tegra 4 - (the significance of this headline)
Message.Msg: Qualcomm not afraid of Tegra 4 think about that headline ... By any measure, QCOM is clearly in a defensive posture vs. T4 . T4 has captured the imaginations of tech reporters, reviewer, bloggers, and consumers. From a PR perspective QCOM is on their heels and that translates into incredible good will and fabulous PR for NVDA. It also creates mojo with OEMs looking for differentiation and association with a hot chip thatalso happens to be cheaper, smaller and better battery life - not to mention a huge win with always on HDR Its bold prediction, but I predict Tegra reveneus to triple in its run rate business 12 months from now And that will means we can see $20 + If we're still an independent business, I think T4 has raised a lot of eyebrows , shield is going to shock the world in shipments , revn contribution and NVDA will be considering multiple proposals if they are not already Longer than ever

Topic.Title: Qualcomm not afraid of Tegra 4 - (the significance of this headline)

Message.Msg: I totally agree. And, you're spot on with "IF we're still an independent business". As I said, yesterday, the appointment of Marty Edelman (who I've known for 40 years) to the AMD BoD strikes me as having 2 possible reasons. One is that Marty is closely tied to BIG money in Abu Dhabi, and perhaps AMD invited him onto the board to secure more investment dollars. However, Marty is VERY smart and extremely well-connected, and is nobody's fool. And while J777 had a cute/funny idea of them turning their Austin campus into condos (and I think he was just joking), I doubt they'd bring Marty onto the Board just to help with that kind of real estate transaction. He does have a lot of M&A experience, too, and if they're shopping the company, he would be great in negotiations, etc. That said, IF that were to come to pass, any bid for AMD would put a major bid into NVDA's stock, and we'd see a 20-50% move possibly overnight. And, with AMD gone (likely to QCOM), NVDA would be "in play" and we might not get the chance to reap the full rewards of what our roadmap would bring. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Best, Max P.S. We are AT the 200DMA as I type.

Message.Msg: push it over $13 for sure...maybe all the way to $14. Love the dividend....Don't you?

The chip vendors, including Nvidia, seem to have switched to a model where the phone vendors are the first to announce their own phones. And the phone vendors aren't eager to tip their hat about new models. It might cause customers to wait for the new model, and could make them vulnerable to "supply issue". I recall Intel was notorious for their treatment of vendors that also built products using non-Intel chips. They would be the last to receiver their chips, and the first to be skipped when there were chip shortages. That was illegal, but complaining would put you out of business.
Thanks - these newsletters are getting creative

Good find! But not too surprising - I don't think they can run the clock as high as T4 - they would need to install a fire hydrant right above it before trying :) This more or less confirms T4's lead for the next 2 Years! It would take everybody else to use 20nm technology to run it cooler. T4 is MAGIC! Don't be surprise with a dual A15 at higher clock rates in a phone instead due to the heat issue with Quads. At 20nm the generic A15 guys would finally be able to match T4 at 28nm but by then the T4 as is in 20nm can run at an even higher clock cycle and still draw less power than it is today! :) So T4 really have a 3 to 4 years lead!! Awesome Awesome Awesome

Topic.Title: Ballmer and Schmidt seen @ NVDA booth - the exchange...

Message.Msg: Link please - this is cool and right on in terms of the impact of T4/T4i on the ARM market. Now, if the above is true - do you think they would have any reservations using T4/T4i in their products - the next super charged RT, Win8 Phone, Mot X, N7/N7.7/10, Chrome Puppy :) ... don't think so.

You said, "not surprising!". Well, up until now, most tech journalists had assumed that Exynos 5 Octa would performa at the same level as Tegra 4 - or even better, since there are 8 cores in octa. This goes to show the ignorance and audacity of most tech pundits who don't even understand that only 4 A15 cores in Exynos Octa are performing cores, and the rest are for house keeping chores/energy management. I do think that this revelation would surprise some analysts and tech writers.

You are right about the analysts and tech writers - they laid off journalists from traditional brick and mortar trying to earn a living in a new space with a mentally lazy approach. If you have serious heat problems - you crank down the GHz and you can claim you have a working Octa/A15 or you hook up a elaborate heat sink to get it to clock higher. What surprises me was why they need 4 A7s to do house keeping when Nvidia needs only one - I hope it's because Nvidia has a patent protection for the use of one CPU for low power house keeping? If so - that's great less complexity and less silicon and cost and power.

Hmmm, I'm surprised that the T4 is so much better in performance. I expected the octo-core to have the performance edge, at least for burst performance until the package heated up and power capping kicked in. Don't expect the T4 to remain the performance leader for two years though. I don't see any likely competitors, which might give them a full six months. In a slower moving market, the next battle would be with a 64 bit ARMv8 implementation. But there is too much at stake to allow Nvidia to be on top until the end of the year.

If power is no issue, if cost is no issue (ala Apple), if ramp volume is no issue as in initial 28nm ramp problems, anybody can come up with a better performing AP - why do you think Intel is struggling so badly after 3 years at it. They boast their dual core is as powerful as a Quad core Arm but if you look underneath the hood - their Dual core is much larger than an Arm quad core! The 64 bit Arms would be too expensive and to power hungry to run in a Phone. So T4 will lead in performance and cost in Phone applications and tablets for at least 4 years.

Between the 64 bit Project Denver and Tegra 4, there is still Logen, Tegra 5, to be released in 2014 hopefully. By all accounts there will be major architectural changes going from Wayne to Logan. So...let's just wait and see what's in store for us. I wouldn't make a preemptive statement about T4's successor being "expensive and power hungry".
Intel's I7 is even more powerful than T4, but this power has its price. We don't have a winner until there is an independent benchmark for energy drain.

Why surprised? Antutu measures the overall performance - both CPU and GPU. The Exynos 5 Octa reportedly has a "currentl -generation" in PowerVR 544 - that's considered very mundane by today's standard. I think Exynos 5 Octa's Antutu number is about where it should be. Ref on Exynos 5 Octa graphics: see Engadget article engadgetDOTcom/2013/01/14/samsung-exynos-5-octa-gpu-rumor/ I am also wondering what happened to the original Mali graphic chip? Seems like everything is falling apart on the Octa. Perhaps Samsung jinxed itself by insisting that this was a eigh-core SoC. lol

Tegra 4 test with tablets not being held Exynos 5 test with an actual phone Lenovo K900 (intel powered) phone scored 25,138 (on video at MWC) androidauthorityDOTcom/lenovo-k900-intel-clover-trail-plus-benchmark-161440/

Message.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia
Message.Msg: Application Processors iPods, iTV, iPads & iPhones - 300m units. LTE modems - 150m units.Total LTE + AP chips - 450m units Savings using NVDA equivalent Chips ~ $15 average per chip. Apple Chips are typically very large - larger than QCOM's for any given performance, and QCOM modem is not cheap. Total savings - 450m X $15 = $6.75B per year. Over 2 Years - $13.5B + $1B Profits from GPU related busineses = $14.5B Approx 2X current price Apple will benefit even more than the $14.5B due to opportunity loss for any further delays in bringing an T4/T4i class product to market! It is impossible for Apple to get the 28nm capacity immediately today from TSMC - Samsung's 28nm is far from mature! AND it's almost impossible for Apple to come up with an A15 class APU using Power VR without the associated power issues - this will be their biggest challenge in the next 6 months! So NVDA's worth to Apple is far beyond pps - well of course they can get the milk for free by just buying Nvidia's APUs instead of buying the company. That is short sighted and shows a lack of understanding of the implications of the T4/T4i achievements and lack of understanding of the chip technology. Buying Nvidia locks everybody out of using the most advance APUs etc for a long time to come and provides a clear evolutionary path, a clear low risk path to the next two to three generations of market leading APUs with little to know risk. Infact anybody who wants to be in the hardware business in a big way would be wise to consider the above implications. MSFT and Goog are not serious in the hardware space. Samsung & Apple are - HP may be.

Topic.Title: Finally A very good reason for Apple to consider Nvidia

Message.Msg: 1/ Management, specifically CEO/Founder Jensen Huang would very likely make it difficult for any company to reach an agreement to acquire NVDA, unless he gets to head the resulting company or NVDA gets a nearly-impossible-to-imagine guarantee that he'll get to run NVDA as a fully autonomous subsidiary. He's a man with a vision and extreme confidence/ego. He's driven by more than wealth... or fiduciary responsibility (or more accurately, I think all of his comments suggest he actually believes it's in shareholders long term interest to let him execute on his vision). Watch videos of him presenting, listen to CCs or at least read the transcripts, and that might help reset your hopes/expectations about how likely it is that management would even enter into negotiations where he wouldn't clearly remain as an autonomous leader of the company he build. Also see the reporting on how AMD wanted to acquire NVDA over ATI and why it didn't work out for a reference, then revisit the CCs/videos and ask yourself he seems to have grown more or less confident over time. 2/ MSFT apparently still has ROFR and ROLR from the deal struck way back with the first XBOX when NVDA was a tiny company. The company still discloses this in their SEC filings, easy to find, but the details aren't public so it's impossible to know what exactly the terms are and if they'd actually apply in a realistic scenario, or if NVDA just continually discloses it as a disincentive for would-be acquirers, but if that's the case, refer to point #1 Could MSFT, GOOG, or AAPL make an offer that NVDA's board would have to consider? Sure. Will they? Maybe... but I wouldn't suggest basing trades on the thesis that it'll happen, and haven't seen anyone doing significant research & analysis on the company suggesting it will. And this is coming from someone that's still sitting on quite a few OTM calls (mostly leaps).
